words.def: A large key which locks levers or other items of signalling apparatus, thereby serving as a portable form of interlocking[citation needed]
words.name: Annett's key

words.def: The indication displayed by a colour-light signal (e.g. a yellow aspect)
words.name: Aspect

words.def: A passenger coach fitted with a driving cab and controls for use in an autotrain
words.name: Autocoach

words.def: The specific form of limited cab signalling introduced in 1948 in the United Kingdom to help train drivers observe and obey warning signals
words.name: Automatic warning system (AWS)

words.def: D5900 class Bo-Bo diesel-electric locomotives, constructed by the English Electric company. They used a single Napier Deltic engine/generator combination, as opposed to the two-engines layout and Co-Co wheel arrangement of the much longer Deltic locomotives from the same manufacturer, to which they bore a very strong family resemblance.[1]
words.name: Baby Deltic

words.def: North British D6300 class locomotives, which used one diesel engine coupled to a hydraulic transmission, making them effectively half a D600 Warship or D800 Warship, each of which had two engines[2]
words.name: Baby Warship

words.def: British Rail Class 33/1 locomotives, specifically those fitted for push-pull working with 4TC stock[3]
words.name: Bagpipes

words.def: Livery of First Group's bus and rail companies up until February 2006—the name comes from the purple and pink packaging of Barbie dolls. First Group are now favouring Neon schemes.[citation needed]
words.name: Barbie

words.def: An iron or steel plate used to spread the weight of rail over a larger area of sleeper (tie) and facilitate a secure, low maintenance, fastening with bolts or clips
words.name: Base plate

words.def: A name used for the service that used to operate between Bedford and London St. Pancras; this service has subsequently been replaced by cross-London service on the Thameslink route. It is sometimes used when referring to the line from Bedford to St Pancras, and not any service in particular.[4][5]
words.name: Bed pan

words.def: The British Railways emblem used from 1949 to 1956, featuring a lion standing astride a wheel on a bar featuring the legend 'British Railways'. This name is derived from the fact the lion is standing astride the wheel like a cyclist – hence the nickname. This was replaced with the Ferret and Dartboard logo in 1956 as the British Railways logo.
words.name: Bicycling Lion

words.def: A LMS Stanier Class 5 4-6-0. Class of steam locomotive built in the UK, named from their black 'mixed-traffic' livery and 'Class 5' power rating.[6]
words.name: Black Five

words.def: The Crimson and Cream livery used on BR's coaches during the 1950s and 60s[7]
words.name: Blood and Custard

words.def: British Rail Class 57 diesel-electric locomotives—made by transplanting a General Motors reconditioned power unit and alternator into a Class 47 bodyshell[8]
words.name: Bodysnatcher

words.def: The undercarriage assembly of rolling stock incorporating the train wheels, suspension, brakes and, in powered units, the traction motors
words.name: Bogie

words.def: The safety certificate issued for a steam (locomotive) boiler on passing a thorough formal inspection and generally covering a period of ten years. The formal inspection usually requires the removal of the boiler from the locomotive and renewal of some parts such as the tubes. Additional annual safety inspections must also be undertaken, which may result in the locomotive being withdrawn from service until any faults are rectified. When the boiler ticket "expires" the locomotive cannot be used until the boiler has been reinspected and a new ticket obtained.[9][improper synthesis?]
words.name: Boiler ticket

words.def: British Rail Class 58 diesel-electric locomotive—from the shape: the body is narrow with wide cabs. (Also called egg timer.) Ironically, one of the final workings of this class was a railfan special called the Bone Breaker which ended in a bufferstop collision and a passenger breaking his leg.[10]
words.name: Bone

words.def: London Underground A60 and A62 Stock, due to the shakey ride of the old trains. The nickname was coined by an ITV News reporter during a report on the A Stock's last day of service on the Metropolitan Line.[11]
words.name: Bone Shaker

words.def: A heavy vehicle with powerful brakes which was attached to the rear of goods trains in the days when most wagons were not fitted with a continuous braking system. Its function was to supplement the locomotive's braking power in slowing and stopping the train and to keep the couplings uniformly tight by selective light braking to avoid snatching and breakages. It also conveyed the train guard, hence its alternative name of "guards van". Partly analogous to caboose and its synonyms.
words.name: Brake van

words.def: British Rail Class 47 diesel-electric locomotive, also known as the "Brush Type 4". Followers of this type are often known as "Brush bashers".
words.name: Brush

words.def: A British Rail Class 121 or 122 single railcar[12][13][14]
words.name: Bubble car

words.def: A steel rail section commonly used in 60 ft lengths on almost all railway lines throughout Britain until c1950, which due to its shape must be supported in cast iron chairs that are screwed to the sleepers. It is still found on some London Underground lines, on secondary and preserved lines and in yards. The rail has two heads (shaped somewhat like a vertical dumbbell) which led some people to assume that when one side became worn, the rail could be inverted and reinstalled for further service rather than being replaced (it can't, because the two heads are different sizes, and by the time the top became worn down sufficiently to fit in the chairs when the rail is inverted, both the top and the bottom of the rail would be too small for further use).
words.name: Bullhead rail

words.def: The superelevation angle of a track (the relative level of one rail to the other), typically around a curve
words.name: Cant

words.def: A British Railways telegraphic codeword to note the cancellation of a passenger train service[15]
words.name: Cape

words.def: A specialized freight car for transporting automobiles[16][17]
words.name: Car transporter wagon or car transporter van

words.def: Passengers (particularly commuters, who often complain that they are treated "like cattle")[18]
words.name: Cattle

words.def: The area either side of the railway immediately off the ballast shoulder which provides a safe area for workers to stand when trains approach[19]
words.name: Cess

words.def: A cast iron bracket screwed to the sleeper and used to support bull head rail that is held in place by a wooden key (wedge) or spring steel clip—still found on preserved railways and in yards
words.name: Chair

words.def: A double rail section of track, sometimes found in train yards and on bridges to prevent derailments or limit damage caused by derailments, by having rail on both sides of the wheel flange. Also found on curves with a tight radius and switches and crossings[20]
words.name: Check rail

words.def: A smokestack
words.name: Chimney, funnel, or stack

words.def: British Rail Class 20 diesel-electric locomotive[21]
words.name: Chopper

words.def: Originally used to describe the exhaust of steam locomotives, "clag" is a term describing the often spectacular (particularly blackened, as in Class 37, or whitesmoked, as in Class 55) exhaust emissions of many older British diesel locomotives, especially, Classes 52 and 55.[22]
words.name: Clag

words.def: Railway vehicle for use in passenger trains[23][24]
words.name: Coach

words.def: Applied to the shape of SR Q1 class steam locomotives[25]
words.name: Coffee pot

words.def: A passenger car with more than one class of accommodation provided (e.g. first and third). In earlier days of three-class travel, first and second class, and second and third class composites were also built. A car with first, second, and third classes was also known as a tri-composite.
words.name: Composite

words.def: The drive rod connecting the crosshead to a driving-wheel or axle in a steam locomotive[26]
words.name: Connecting rod

words.def: The mechanical connector at either end of a railroad car allowing it to couple together with other cars to form a train[27]
words.name: Coupling (UK)

words.def: British Rail Class 33 diesel-electric locomotive (fitted with Crompton Parkinson electrical equipment).[28] See also Slim Jim.
words.name: Crompton

words.def: British Rail Class 460 Juniper electric multiple units (EMUs), so called due to their sloping cab ends, which resembled the front of the helmet worn by the Star Wars villain of the same name
words.name: Darth Vaders

words.def: British Rail Class 55 diesel-electric locomotives (the "Deltics"), which use twin Napier Deltic power units
words.name: Deltics

words.def: A small explosive device strapped to the top of a rail to alert an approaching train of danger ahead by creating a loud noise upon contact with a locomotive wheel[29]
words.name: Detonator

words.def: Waggon und Maschinenbau railbuses E79960-64, introduced 1958[30]
words.name: Doodlebug

words.def: The operator of a railway locomotive
words.name: Driver

words.def: A passenger coach which has a full set of train controls at one end, allowing for the use of push-pull train operation[33]
words.name: Driving trailer

words.def: A class of control cars
words.name: Driving Van Trailer (DVT)

words.def: British Rail Class 321, from the game show 3-2-1, featuring the animated character "Dusty Bin"[34]
words.name: Dusty Bin

words.def: The livery of British Rail Civil Engineers department rolling stock, due to the resemblance of Nederlandse Spoorwegen's corporate livery[35]
words.name: Dutch

words.def: British Rail Class 92 so called because of the sound their traction blowers make as they go past
words.name: Dyson

words.def: British Rail Class 58 diesel-electric locomotive[10]
words.name: Egg Timer

words.def: The original livery of the First Great Western HSTs—a basically green colour scheme, fading to ivory, with shiny gold stripe, below the windows,[36] so called because it resembles the packaging of a brand of Rothman's cigarettes ('fags')
words.name: Fag packet livery

words.def: The second British Railways emblem introduced in 1956, featuring a lion rampant holding a wheel. From a distance the wheel has a passing resemblance to a dartboard.[37]
words.name: Ferret and Dartboard

words.def: A metal plate that joins the ends of rails in jointed track[38]
words.name: Fishplate

words.def: A junction in which all track crossings take place at grade and routings must therefore be controlled by signals and interlocking
words.name: Flat junction

words.def: A type of rolling stock, which can be a flat-bottomed car with no sides on which freight (including intermodal containers) can be stacked. A bulkhead is a flatcar with walls on the front and rear. A center-beam bulkhead is a bulkhead flatcar with an additional wall dividing one side of the flatcar from the other, but still without any sides.[39]
words.name: Flat wagon

words.def: The practice of uncoupling a locomotive from a car in motion and running over a switch, whereupon an employee on the ground lines the switch to divert the car onto an adjacent track.[40][41] Once commonplace, this practice has led to several lawsuits against railroad companies and is now strictly prohibited due to the high risk to life and property.[42][43][44][45][46]
words.name: Fly shunting

words.def: The first design of GWR diesel railcars, introduced in 1932.[47] This has since been adopted for the Network Rail New Measurement Train, due to its all-over yellow livery.[48] Also occasionally used to describe the High Speed Train.[49]
words.name: Flying Banana

words.def: The group of rail vehicles making up a train, or more commonly a group of locomotives connected together for multiple-unit (MU) operation[27]
words.name: Formation

words.def: The products which are carried
words.name: Goods

words.def: A type of rolling stock with a flat bottom enclosed on all sides and top, which is loaded and unloaded from sliding doors on each side[50][51]
words.name: Goods van, goods wagon, or goods truck, railway wagon, or wagon

words.def: A British Rail Class 31 diesel-electric locomotive—from "gargoyle" (after the somewhat ungainly headcode boxes above the driving cabs)[52]
words.name: Goyle

words.def: A rail enthusiast[53][54][55]
words.name: Gricer

words.def: A British Rail Class 56 diesel-electric locomotive, from the large grilles[56]
words.name: Grid or grid iron

words.def: A British Rail Class 08 shunter[57]
words.name: Gronk

words.def:
A British Rail Class 37 diesel-electric locomotive (from the engine sound)[58]
A nickname for the 20 Metropolitan-Vickers electric locomotives used on London's Metropolitan underground railway between Liverpool Street and Rickmansworth. The name derived from the noise these locomotives made.[59][citation needed]
words.name: Growler

words.def: The person in charge of a train and its crew. On passenger trains, a conductor is also responsible for tasks such as assisting passengers and collecting tickets.
words.name: Guard

words.def: A nickname for the British Rail Class 31, on account of its engine noise[49]
words.name: Gurgler

words.def: A length of track feeding a number of sidings that permits the sidings to be shunted without blocking the main line, or where two lines merge into one before ending with a buffer, to allow a run-round procedure to take place[60]
words.name: Headshunt

words.def: A British Rail Class 50 diesel-electric locomotive—from the sound of the engine cooling fans being similar to a vacuum cleaner, prior to the refurbishment which removed this characteristic[61]
words.name: Hoover

words.def: A D7000 class locomotive using a V16 Maybach diesel engine coupled to a Mekydro hydraulic transmission[62]
words.name: Hymek

words.def: A British Rail Class 365 because their revised front end gives a happy face style[63]
words.name: Happy Train

words.def: British Rail Class 395 electric multiple units, due to their usage during the London 2012 Summer Olympics on Olympic Javelin Shuttle services[64]
words.name: Javelin

words.def: A railway station at which tracks and facilities are shared by two or more railways[65]
words.name: Joint station

words.def: A British Rail HS4000
words.name: Kestrel

words.def: Timber or sprung steel block used to secure Bullhead rail into the chairs[66]
words.name: Key

words.def: A portable (often handheld) light source that is used to signal train crews[67]
words.name: Lamp

words.def: One of the first new British Rail locomotive liveries applied after many years of all-over rail blue. For this livery, the loco cabs were entirely 'warning yellow', with black window surrounds (the yellow usually wrapping round behind the cab doors); the main bodysides were still rail blue but featured very large running numbers with a large white British Rail 'double arrow' logo in the middle, the full height of the body. It was applied to refurbished Class 50 locomotives, among others.[68]
words.name: Large logo livery

words.def: The cutter's torch, coined by Modern Railways magazine as a pun on the Class 460 'Darth Vaders' having their front ends cut off as part of the amalgamation with the Class 458s[citation needed]
words.name: Lightsaber

words.def: A trackside cabinet used to house signalling equipment such as relays or transformers[69][70]
words.name: Location case

words.def: A second parallel track (running for a short distance) on single-track railway lines, allowing a train to pass another
words.name: Loop

words.def: A principal artery of a railway system[71]
words.name: Main line

words.def: Coal train running between a coal mine and a power station, loading and unloading without stopping or shunting
words.name: Merry-go-round (MGR) train

words.def: Locomotives constructed by Metropolitan-Vickers, especially the British Rail Class 28 (D5700 class) Co-Bo[72]
words.name: Metrovick

words.def: A Ivatt 2MT class 2-6-0 steam locomotive[73]
words.name: Mickey Mouse

words.def: Collective term for the connecting rod, coupling rods, and valve gear—forms part of the running gear[74]
words.name: Motion

words.def: A branch-line train consisting of a steam locomotive and passenger carriages that can be driven from either end by means of rodding to the regulator and an additional vacuum brake valve. The fireman remains with the locomotive and, when the driver is at the other end, the fireman controls the cut off and vacuum ejectors in addition to his usual duties.
words.name: Motor train

words.def: A high-speed train consisting of one MTU engined power car, and one Valenta engined power car in the formation
words.name: MTVal

words.def: The ability of diesel and electric locomotives or multiple units to be joined together and controlled from one driving station. Such a set of joined locomotives is called a consist or (colloquially) "lash-up" and is said to be "MUed together".[71]
words.name: Multiple working

words.def: A British Rail Class 168 Clubman unit with original front end, so called because it resembles the front end of a Networker
words.name: Networker Clubman

words.def: A non-enthusiast[75]
words.name: Normal

words.def: The British Rail Pacer Unit because of their bouncing up and down (nodding), and the donkey-like sound such units make on tight corners due to their lack of bogies[citation needed]
words.name: Nodding Donkeys

words.def: A type of rolling stock with a flat bottom and relatively low sides, used to haul material such as ore or scrap, and loaded and unloaded from the top which may be covered or uncovered[20][76]
words.name: Open wagon

words.def: A bridge over the railway[77]
words.name: Overbridge

words.def: A distance (normally 180 metres or set according to the permitted speed of the line) beyond a stop signal which must be clear before the preceding stop signal can display a proceed aspect; allows a margin in case a train overshoots a signal before stopping[78]
words.name: Overlap

words.def: A British Rail Class 44, Class 45, or Class 46 diesel-electric locomotive—so named because the earliest of these loco types, the ten Class 44s, were named after mountains[79]
words.name: Peak

words.def: The railway or contractor's official responsible for safe working during engineer's possession[80]
words.name: Person in charge of possession (PICOP)

words.def: A British Rail Class 442, "Wessex Electrics" (electric multiple units)—so-named for being mostly made out of plastics in construction[citation needed]
words.name: Plastic pig

words.def: A motor or device which operates points
words.name: Point machine

words.def: The articulating rails that determine the route to be taken
words.name: Points

words.def: A British Rail Class 70, a reference to the alien of the same name from the American films[citation needed]
words.name: Predator

words.def: A small, hand-powered railroad car used for track inspection
words.name: Pump trolley

words.def: A set of rolling stock coupled together[81][82]
words.name: Rake

words.def: British Rail Class 25 diesel-electric locomotives—and related classes—reputedly originating from a term used on the LMR of British Rail in the 1960s where 25s were as common as "rats";[83] the Scottish-based Class 26 and 27 were sometimes known as "MacRats".[84] See also Splut.
words.name: Rat

words.def: South West Trains, coined by Modern Railways as a pun on the Darth Vader front ends of the Class 460s being cut off as part of the amalgamation with the Class 458 units (which amidst the pun was dubbed as their 'star fleet', all a pun on Star Wars)[citation needed]
words.name: Rebel Alliance

words.def: Early British Rail 25 kV AC electric locomotive of types 'AL1'–'AL5' (later Classes 81, 82, 83, 84, 85), due to the loud whine made by the traction motor cooling fans when the locomotive is at rest. The name originated with the AL3 type. Although the other types exhibit a less noticeable noise, the name is applied equally to any of them.[85]
words.name: Roarer

words.def: The legal right of one railway company to use the tracks of another, as agreed to by the companies concerned or their predecessors[29]
words.name: Running powers

words.def: A Canadian-built Class 66 diesel-electric locomotive (from the roof shape and also the corrugated bodysides)[86]
words.name: Shed

words.def:
A small locomotive used for assembling trains and moving railroad cars around[87]
A person involved in such work[87]
words.name: Shunter

words.def: An incident when a train passes a stop signal
words.name: Signal passed at danger (SPAD)

words.def: A direct no-dial telephone link to the relevant signal box, positioned on or near a signal[88]
words.name: Signal-post telephone (SPT)

words.def: China Clay slurry wagons[89]
words.name: Silver bullet

words.def: Class 67 diesel-electric locomotive (from its shape—an upside down skip)[citation needed]
words.name: Skip

words.def: Class 142 DMUs[90]
words.name: Skipper

words.def: A temporary speed restriction to protect, for example, sections of track in poor condition and awaiting repair. Also applies to the timing tolerance included in timetable schedules to allow for such restrictions.[citation needed]
words.name: Slack

words.def: Looseness in a train caused by mating clearances in couplers[87]
words.name: Slack action

words.def: Any diesel or electric multiple unit with manually opening hinged doors (mostly the British rail classes 423 and 421), so called after the noise made by passengers slamming the doors
words.name: Slam-door train

words.def: Bars of wood or concrete placed beneath and perpendicular to track to support the rails[29]
words.name: Sleeper

words.def: Narrow-bodied version of the British Rail Class 33 diesel-electric locomotive (identified as sub-class 33/2)—built for the confined loading gauge on the Hastings line.[49] See also Crompton).
words.name: Slim Jim

words.def: A passenger coach that is disconnected from a train without the train having to stop. While the train continued on its route, the slip coach would be guided and stopped by a guard on board using the coach's own brake mechanism. This practice was almost entirely limited to the United Kingdom and was discontinued in the 1960s.[91][92]
words.name: Slip coach

words.def: Another nickname for the British Rail Class 25, referring to their habit of spluttering when their engines cut out and failed, which they often did.[93] See also Rat.
words.name: Splut

words.def: A shunting engine based at a major passenger station and used for passenger-train shunting duties
words.name: Station pilot

words.def: A now-defunct British Railways rule which required a train crew to stop the train and examine the cause of an unexpected noise, vibration, etc.[94] Section TW of the Network Rail rulebook covers the requirements when working a modern train.
words.name: Stop and examine

words.def: A tunnel passing underneath the railway tracks to allow passengers to cross from one platform to another
words.name: Subway

words.def: A rebuilt class 60, upgraded by DBS. Mainly seen in an overall red livery, with half-yellow fronts, but a couple can be seen in the original Sector livery.
words.name: Super 60

words.def: The banking of railroad track on curves. Specifically, the practice on high speed lines (where the cant needs to be higher) of gently introducing the elevation of the outer rail before the bend starts, in order to avoid sudden lurches. Synonymous with cant.[87]
words.name: Superelevation

words.def: 3R DEMUs. Named due to having two vehicles 8 ft 2½ in wide and one vehicle 9 ft 3 in wide.[95]
words.name: Tadpole

words.def: A locomotive that carries its own fuel and water instead of hauling a tender
words.name: Tank engine

words.def: A British Rail Class 14 diesel-hydraulic locomotive for shunting and trip working.[86] Coined by Swindon Works' foreman George Cole who quipped "We've built the Great Bear, now we're going to build a Teddy Bear!".[96]
words.name: Teddy Bear

words.def: A station sited where a railway line or service ends or terminates
words.name: Terminus (UK)

words.def: The LB&SCR A1 Class 0-6-0 steam locomotive, on account of its distinctive "bark" when running[97]
words.name: Terrier

words.def: An illuminated number usually attached to signal indicating arrival platform for train approaching a station[citation needed]
words.name: Theatre indicator

words.def: Class 52 diesel-hydraulic locomotives (the "Westerns") given the number range beginning with D1000[98]
words.name: Thousands

words.def: Southern DEMU (BR Classes 201–207)—unlike conventional DMUs these used a single, comparatively large diesel engine and electric generator mounted immediately behind one driving cab. The power units made a distinctive "thumping" noise when working hard.[99][citation needed]
words.name: Thumper

words.def: A locomotive kept on standby at a strategic location, ready to rescue a failed train—from Thunderbirds[100]
words.name: Thunderbird

words.def: The livery used by Network SouthEast. So called due to the red, white and blue colours resembling the colours of striped toothpaste.[101][not in citation given]
words.name: Toothpaste

words.def: A train with locomotives at both ends, for ease of changing direction
words.name: Top and tail

words.def: A British Rail Class 37 diesel-electric locomotive, possibly from the engine sound, also because they could be found hauling almost anything as a mixed-traffic design[102]
words.name: Tractor

words.def: The operator of a locomotive[103]
words.name: Train driver

words.def: The locomotive closest to the train during a double-heading operation
words.name: Train engine

words.def: A book or loose-leaf sheets kept in a signal box and used to record the passage of trains, messages passed, and other prescribed events[104]
words.name: Train register

words.def: Three railway tracks in a triangular form with points at all three corners—can be used to turn a train around[105]
words.name: Triangle

words.def: A British Rail Class 60 diesel-electric locomotive, as named because of their tremendous pulling power, size and sluggish nature. Class 60s upgraded by DB Schenker are called 'Super Tugs'.[106]
words.name: Tug

words.def: A Southern Railway U class 2-6-0 steam locomotive[107]
words.name: U-Boat

words.def: A bridge carrying the railway and allowing a roadway to pass under the railway[108]
words.name: Underbridge

words.def: A direction (usually towards London, other capital city, or the headquarters of the railway concerned) or side (on left-running railways, the left side when facing in the up direction). The opposite of down. The up direction is usually associated with even-numbered trains and signals.[citation needed]
words.name: Up

words.def: A type of rolling stock with a flat bottom enclosed on all sides and top, which is loaded and unloaded from sliding doors on each side[50][51]
words.name: Van

words.def: A D600 or D800 class diesel-hydraulic locomotives, most of which were named after Royal Navy vessels[109]
words.name: Warship

words.def: A device used for delivering a large volume of water into the tank or tender of a steam locomotive
words.name: Water crane

words.def: A British Rail Class 442 electric multiple unit—from the "Wessex Electric" brand name used at launch[110]
words.name: Wessie

words.def: A British Rail Class 52 diesel-hydraulic type 4 locomotive, 74 of which ran on BR between 1961 and 1977. All were named in a series beginning "Western...". Seven of the class have been preserved.[111]
words.name: Western

words.def: A British Rail Class 40 diesel-electric locomotive, from the turbocharger sound; this nickname is also occasionally applied to British Rail Class 20 locomotives.[112]
words.name: Whistler

words.def: A British Rail Class 52 diesel-hydraulic type 4 locomotive[113]
words.name: Wizzo

words.def: A South Eastern and Chatham Railway N class 2-6-0 steam locomotive, built at Woolwich Arsenal[114]
words.name: Woolworth

words.def: A derogatory nickname for FirstGroup, especially on First Great Western "Worst Late Western"[18] (since re-branded as Great Western Railway[115][116]) and First Capital Connect "Worst Crapital Disconnect" (since ceased operations[117]) or First Hull Trains "Worst Hell Trains"
words.name: Worst or WorstGroup

words.def: An early name for a Class 59 diesel-electric locomotive, the first privately owned (by Foster Yeoman) locomotives to operate on British Rail, owing to their names starting with "Yeoman" such as 59 001 Yeoman Endeavour[118]
words.name: Yeoman
